habitat_description:
The distribution of this species is primarily restricted to the Gulf of Mexico. Juveniles occupy the Gulf of Mexico and also the U. S. Atlantic coast north to Long Island, New England, and Nova Scotia. Some reports include observations in Bermuda, the Azores, and European waters (Morreale et al. 1992; USFWS 1992; 1998). Main foraging areas include Campeche Bay, Mexico, and Louisiana coastal regions (Ogren 1992). Individuals also visit beaches on northern Long Island, New York in late fall or early winter for foraging as well (Burke et al. 1991; Morreale et al. 1992).

Nesting usually occurs on beaches backed up by large swamps or open water bodies that are characterized by having seasonal, narrow access to the ocean (Natureserve.org).  Tamaulipas, Mexico harbors the single most important nesting beach; Rancho Nuevo. This area provides a 40 kilometer stretch of suitable nesting terrain (Natureserve.org). Minor and sporadic nesting has been reported as far north as North Carolina and as far south to Colombia (Palmatier 1993). This benthic species burrows in or using soil. The habitat can be said to be primarily near shore habitat; bays, tidal flats, and sand dunes. The habitat occupied by adults consists of shallow coastal and estuarine waters that possess muddy or sandy bottoms with abundant crab. Most activity is categorized as benthic. Hatchlings spend 1 to 4 years as surface pelagic drifters in weed lines of offshore drawings in the Gulf of Mexico and Atlantic Ocean. As they mature, they shift to benthic coastal environments dominated by crabs and other invertebrates (Natureserve.org).
